raw_text: Pronunciation modeling in (Toutanova and Moore, 2002) further improves spelling correction performance
clean_text: Pronunciation modeling in (Toutanova and Moore, 2002) further improves spelling correction performance.

raw_text: (Toutanova and Moore, 2002) improved the string to string edits model by modeling pronunciation similarities between words
clean_text: (Toutanova and Moore, 2002) improved the string to string edits model by modeling pronunciation similarities between words.

citing_paper_authors: Richard, Beaufort | Sophie, Roekhaut | Louise-Amélie, Cougnon | Cédrick, Fairon
raw_text: (2007) implemented the noisy channel through a Hidden-Markov Model (HMM) able to handle both graphemic variants and phonetic plays as proposed by (Toutanova and Moore, 2002), while Cook and Stevenson (2009) enhanced the model by adapting the channel? s noise P (O|W ,wf) according to a list of predefined observed word formations {wf}: stylistic variation, word clipping, phonetic abbreviations, etc. Whatever the system, the main limitation of the spell checking approach is the excessive confidence it places in word boundaries
clean_text: Choudhury et al. (2007) implemented the noisy channel through a Hidden-Markov Model (HMM) able to handle both graphemic variants and phonetic plays as proposed by (Toutanova and Moore, 2002), while Cook and Stevenson (2009) enhanced the model by adapting the channel's noise P (O|W, wf) according to a list of predefined observed word formations {wf}: stylistic variation, word clipping, phonetic abbreviations, etc.

citing_paper_authors: Catherine, Kobus | François, Yvon | Géraldine, Damnati
raw_text: The key component here is the error model, which should not only capture orthographic similarities (Brill and Moore, 2000), but also phonetic similarities (Toutanova and Moore, 2002)
clean_text: The key component here is the error model, which should not only capture orthographic similarities (Brill and Moore, 2000), but also phonetic similarities (Toutanova and Moore, 2002).

citing_paper_authors: Qing, Chen | Mu, Li | Ming, Zhou
raw_text: (Brill and Moore, 2000) presented an improved error model over the one proposed by (Kernighan et al, 1990) by allowing generic string-to-string edit operations, which helps with modeling major cognitive errors such as the confusion between le and al. Via explicit modeling of phonetic information of English words, (Toutanova and Moore, 2002) further investigated this issue
clean_text: (Brill and Moore, 2000) presented an improved error model over the one proposed by (Kernighan et al, 1990) by allowing generic string-to-string edit operations, which helps with modeling major cognitive errors such as the confusion between le and al. Via explicit modeling of phonetic information of English words, (Toutanova and Moore, 2002) further investigated this issue.

citing_paper_authors: Casey, Whitelaw | Ben, Hutchinson | Grace Y, Chung | Ged, Ellis
raw_text: This approach has also been extended to incorporate a pronunciation model (Toutanova and Moore, 2002)
clean_text: This approach has also been extended to incorporate a pronunciation model (Toutanova and Moore, 2002).

raw_text: Neither do we require pairs of misspelled names and their correct spellings for learning the error model unlike (Brill and Moore, 2000) or large-coverage general purpose lexicon for unlike (Cucerzan and Brill, 2004) or pronunciation dictionaries unlike (Toutanova and Moore, 2002)
clean_text: Neither do we require pairs of misspelled names and their correct spellings for learning the error model unlike (Brill and Moore, 2000) or large-coverage general purpose lexicon for unlike (Cucerzan and Brill, 2004) or pronunciation dictionaries unlike (Toutanova and Moore, 2002).

citing_paper_authors: Ziqi, Wang | Gu, Xu | Hang, Li | Ming, Zhang
raw_text: For example, Brill and Moore (2000) developed a generative model including contextual substitution rules; and Toutanova and Moore (2002) further improved the model by adding pronunciation factors into the model
clean_text: For example, Brill and Moore (2000) developed a generative model including contextual substitution rules; and Toutanova and Moore (2002) further improved the model by adding pronunciation factors into the model.

raw_text: Toutanova and Moore (2002) improve the model by incorporating pronunciation information
clean_text: Toutanova and Moore (2002) improve the model by incorporating pronunciation information.

citing_paper_authors: Mu, Li | Muhua, Zhu | Yang, Zhang | Ming, Zhou
raw_text: Brill and Moore (2000 )presented an improved error model over the one proposed by Kernigham et al (1990) by allowing generic string-to-string edit operations, which helps with modeling major cognitive errors such as the confusion between le and al. Toutanova and Moore (2002) further explored this via explicit modeling of phonetic information of English words
clean_text: Toutanova and Moore (2002) further explored this via explicit modeling of phonetic information of English words.

raw_text: Our model of pronunciation variation is used to extend a pronouncing dictionary for use in the spelling correction algorithm developed by Toutanova and Moore (2002), which includes models for both orthography and pronunciation
clean_text: Our model of pronunciation variation is used to extend a pronouncing dictionary for use in the spelling correction algorithm developed by Toutanova and Moore (2002), which includes models for both orthography and pronunciation.

raw_text: The pronunciation variation model is used to generate multiple pronunciations for each canonical pronunciation in a pronouncing dictionary and these variations are used in the spelling correction approach developed by Toutanova and Moore (2002), which uses statistical models of spelling errors that consider both orthography and pronunciation
clean_text: The pronunciation variation model is used to generate multiple pronunciations for each canonical pronunciation in a pronouncing dictionary and these variations are used in the spelling correction approach developed by Toutanova and Moore (2002), which uses statistical models of spelling errors that consider both orthography and pronunciation.

raw_text: Toutanova and Moore (2002) extend Brill and Moore (2000) to consider edits over both letter sequences and sequences of phones in the pronunciations of the word and misspelling
clean_text: Toutanova and Moore (2002) extend Brill and Moore (2000) to consider edits over both letter sequences and sequences of phones in the pronunciations of the word and misspelling.

raw_text: The spelling correction models from Brill and Moore (2000) and Toutanova and Moore (2002) use the noisy channel model approach to determine the types and weights of edit operations
clean_text: The spelling correction models from Brill and Moore (2000) and Toutanova and Moore (2002) use the noisy channel model approach to determine the types and weights of edit operations.

raw_text: if? 6=? 2.2.1 Extending to Pronunciation Toutanova and Moore (2002) describe an extension to Brill and Moore (2000) where the same noisy channel error model is used to model phone sequences instead of letter sequences
clean_text: Toutanova and Moore (2002) describe an extension to Brill and Moore (2000) where the same noisy channel error model is used to model phone sequences instead of letter sequences.

raw_text: Since a spelling correction model needs to rank candidate words rather than candidate pronunciations, Toutanova and Moore (2002) derive an error model that determines the probability that a word w was spelled as the non-word r based on their pronunciations
clean_text: Since a spelling correction model needs to rank candidate words rather than candidate pronunciations, Toutanova and Moore (2002) derive an error model that determines the probability that a word w was spelled as the non-word r based on their pronunciations.

raw_text: Like Toutanova and Moore (2002), we use the n-gramLTP model from Fisher (1999) to predict these pronunciations
clean_text: Like Toutanova and Moore (2002), we use the n-gram LTP model from Fisher (1999) to predict these pronunciations.

raw_text: The pronunciation based spelling correction approach developed inToutanova and Moore (2002) requires a list of possible pronunciations in order to compare the pronunciation of the misspelling to the pronunciation of correct words
clean_text: The pronunciation based spelling correction approach developed in Toutanova and Moore (2002) requires a list of possible pronunciations in order to compare the pronunciation of the misspelling to the pronunciation of correct words.

raw_text: In order to evaluate the effect of pronunciation variation in Toutanova and Moore (2002)? s spelling correction approach, we compare the performance of the pronunciation model and the combined model 6OpenFst is available at http: //www.openfst.org/
clean_text: In order to evaluate the effect of pronunciation variation in Toutanova and Moore (2002)'s spelling correction approach, we compare the performance of the pronunciation model and the combined model.

raw_text: The noisy channel spelling correction approach developed by Brill and Moore (2000) and Toutanova and Moore (2002) appears well-suited for writers of English as a foreign language
clean_text: The noisy channel spelling correction approach developed by Brill and Moore (2000) and Toutanova and Moore (2002) appears well-suited for writers of English as a foreign language.
